summary: This is a Department of Justice press release announcing the release of the executive summary of the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report on the 2006-2008 federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It states OPR found no professional misconduct but concluded victims were not treated properly and that former U.S. Attorney Acosta exercised poor judgment in the resolution of the case via a non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Release of OPR Report Executive Summary
events.description: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility releases the executive summary of its report investigating the handling of the Epstein case and victim interactions.

keyFacts: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) investigated the handling of the 2006-2008 federal criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.
OPR did not find that Department attorneys engaged in professional misconduct.
OPR concluded that the victims were not treated with the forthrightness and sensitivity expected by the Department.

OPR concluded that former U.S. Attorney Acosta exercised poor judgment in resolving the investigation via a non-prosecution agreement and in failing to ensure victims were notified of the state plea hearing.
The full OPR report is protected by the Privacy Act but has been disclosed to a congressional committee with jurisdiction.
